channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Biden Reaches Out to Mideast Dictators, His Eyes Are on China and Russia
item.description: Looking to make Moscow pay for its Ukraine war, and box China out of Mideast tech deals, the U.S. president tries to fall back on old Gulf alliances.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia at the Gulf Cooperation Council summit in the Saudi port city of Jeddah on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
item.description: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: School-aged children last year at an award ceremony in Vladimir, Russia.

item.title: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
item.description: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The potential departure of Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, a symbol of European resolve and stability, has unnerved the continent.

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Civilians Warned About Russian Air Strikes
item.description: The plea to heed air raid sirens came as Russia ordered its troops to intensify military action across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers changing teams to go to the front line in the Donetsk Province on Saturday.

item.title: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
item.description: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.

item.title: Dead but Not Buried, Angola’s Ex-President’s Body Sparks a Continental Fight
item.description: José Eduardo dos Santos ruled Angola for 38 years. But he died in Spain. A dispute over where to lay him to rest has divided his family and could decide the fate of his political party.
item.dc:creator: Gilberto Neto, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: With his body still in Spain, a portrait was the official focus of mourning in Luanda this week for José Eduardo dos Santos, Angola’s president from 1979 to 2017.

item.title: Ex-Goddess Works to Reform 700-Year Tradition. Her M.B.A. Helps.
item.description: As a child, Chanira Bajracharya was worshiped in Nepal, but still made time to study. She is now encouraging the girl goddesses who’ve followed her to do the same.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Ms. Bajracharya, then a 12-year-old kumari, in 2007.

item.title: Why the Latest Palestinian Leader in the West Bank Is Unpopular
item.description: Hussein al-Sheikh is considered a possible successor to Mahmoud Abbas, 87, the Palestinian Authority president. But as a liaison to Israel, some critics call him a “spokesman of the occupation.”
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hussein al-Sheikh has become the focus of a debate among Palestinians about the vision and legitimacy of their leaders.

item.title: Biden Offers Differing Messages for Israelis and Palestinians
item.description: To Israelis, President Biden’s visit was mostly a source of celebration of growing ties with Arab countries. For the Palestinians, Mr. Biden brought funding and sympathy — but no long-term plans.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Biden met with the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in the West Bank on Friday, but said that “the ground is not ripe at this moment to restart negotiations” to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Crisis in Draghi Government Dismays Italians
item.description: The prime minister’s success in expanding Italy’s influence left many disbelieving that a part of his coalition would knock the country back onto wobbly footing.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The Five Star Movement’s senators walked out on a confidence vote over Prime Minister Mario Draghi’s government on Thursday.

item.title: The War in Ukraine Is the True Culture War
item.description: With Russia trying to erase Ukraine’s national identity, the fight to preserve, and build upon, Ukraine’s artistic heritage has taken on new urgency.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: As Israelis praise Biden, some Palestinians protest over his visit.
item.description: Demonstrators express frustration with Washington’s support for Israel and the Biden administration’s policies toward Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians protested President Biden’s visit, near Augusta Victoria Hospital in East Jerusalem.

item.title: France Faces a Mustard Shortage
item.description: A perfect storm of climate change, a European war and Covid have left the French scrambling for alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Mustard on sale in Dijon, France, last year. While Dijon mustard is as irreplaceable as it is indispensable, lately French diners have had to do without.

item.title: Lily Safra, Star-Crossed Socialite and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
item.description: Her life was marked by tragedy, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, but that did not stop her from giving away millions.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Lily Safra in 1991. She led what might have seemed to be a charmed life, but the glamour was offset by heartbreak.

item.title: Head of Documenta Resigns Amid Antisemitism Scandal
item.description: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Museum Fridericianum in June during the Documenta contemporary art exhibition in Kassel, Germany.

item.title: Eugenio Scalfari, Leading Italian Journalist, Dies at 98
item.description: As a founder of La Repubblica, one of the country’s major newspapers, and later as a columnist, he left a mark on civic life.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Eugenio Scalfari in 1992. He was a founder of the newspaper La Repubblica, a major force in Italian journalism.

item.title: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
item.description: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A store hit by shelling in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Saturday. Ukrainian military officials said Ukrainian troops repelled an overnight assault by Russia to capture the main road link between the cities of Lysychansk and Bakhmut.

item.title: How Biden’s Mideast Efforts on Oil Resemble Jimmy Carter’s
item.description: Jimmy Carter flew to Tehran in 1977 to meet the shah of Iran.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: President Jimmy Carter toasted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi of Iran during a New Year's Eve dinner at Niavaran Palace in Tehran in 1977.

item.title: Biden Says He Confronted Saudi Prince Over Jamal Khashoggi. How True Is That?
item.description: Mr. Biden is by nature a storyteller with a history of relating dramatic tales of conversations with foreign leaders that others in the room do not recall the same way.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during a summit in Jeddah on Saturday, one day after their encounter.

item.title: Wildfires, and a Heat Wave, Sweep Across Europe
item.description: Fires in the south of France have burned more than 22,000 acres and prompted widespread evacuations. Britain was bracing for record high temperatures early next week.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A restaurant destroyed by flames on Friday near La Teste-de-Buch, in southwestern France.

item.title: Salad Days
item.description: When it comes to making the perfect summer salad, sometimes less is more.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: One Result of Biden’s Meeting With Saudi Prince: A Setback in the Khashoggi Case
item.description: President Biden’s dropping of his resistance to speak with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seems to signal the end of official U.S. efforts to seek justice for the slain journalist.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Saudi officials eventually acknowledged Jamal Khashoggi’s murder, but insisted that it had been carried out by rogue agents with no orders from Riyadh.

item.title: Toronto’s Pearson Airport Struggles With Flight Delays
item.description: Airports around the world are struggling to keep pace with the summer travel boom.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Travelers crowded the security queue in the departures lounge at Toronto Pearson International Airport in May.

item.title: Did Nature Heal During the Pandemic ‘Anthropause’?
item.description: Covid precautions created a global slowdown in human activity — and an opportunity to learn more about the complex ways we affect other species.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lone duck savoring its hegemony over the Place de la Concorde in Paris, during coronavirus pandemic lockdowns in the spring of 2020.

item.title: Getting a Passport Will Be Another Pain for Summer Travels
item.description: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: How We Counted Egypt’s Invisible Detainees
item.description: There was no public accounting of the prisoners in the black hole of Egypt’s indefinite pretrial detention. Until now.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Allison McCann and Josh Holder
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Biden’s Visit to Saudi Arabia Draws Criticism and Modest Accords
item.description: In the most politically problematic trip of his presidency, Mr. Biden’s critics accused him of helping rehabilitate the reputation of a tarnished prince in exchange for numerous, but limited gains.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden’s welcome in Saudi Arabia was polite but perfunctory compared with the enthusiastic greeting President Donald J. Trump received in 2017.

item.title: Demand for Monkeypox Vaccine Exceeds Supply, C.D.C. Says
item.description: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to receive monkeypox vaccinations at a sexual health clinic in New York City.

item.title: 4-Year-Old Girl Dies in Russian Strike in Vinnytsia
item.description: A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a Ukraine park before a Russian missile landed. “I want to shout out to the whole world,” an anguished survivor of the attack cried.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The stroller that Liza Dmytriyeva was pushing before she was killed in the Russian missile attack on Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Mexican Activists Answer Calls for Abortion Pills From the U.S.
item.description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Paula Mónaco Felipe, Caroline Kim, Souleyman Messalti and Miguel Tovar
item.media:credit: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times
item.media:description:
In July, Verónica Cruz Sánchez, the founder and leader of Las Libres in Guanajuato, Mexico responds to a request for abortion pills from the U.S.
NYTCREDIT: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times

item.title: Mexico Captures Notorious Drug Kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero
item.description: Rafael Caro Quintero, an accused drug cartel leader, was convicted of killing Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and was wanted by the F.BI.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Rafael Caro Quintero, center, was convicted of orchestrating the 1985 torture and killing of Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was working undercover in Mexico.

item.title: Biden Said He Rebuked the Saudi Crown Prince Over Khashoggi’s Murder
item.description: Mr. Khashoggi, a Saudi contributor to The Washington Post who was critical of the prince’s rule, was killed in Istanbul in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden’s welcome in Saudi Arabia was polite but perfunctory compared with the enthusiastic greeting President Donald J. Trump received in 2017.

item.title: Four Ways the United States Can Still Fight Climate Change
item.description: With the president’s most potent tools to fight climate change stripped by Congress and the courts, the administration will now have to rely on smaller, less powerful actions.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Manchin’s decision and the Supreme Court decision smashed the building that the Biden administration was constructing to meet this very ambitious climate target,” one legal expert said.

item.title: After 350 Years of Tradition, a Boys’ Choir Now Admits Girls
item.description: The Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, is the latest English choir to start including female singers, a move some fear will reduce opportunities for boys.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

item.title: Recommended Reading on America’s Authoritarian Enclaves
item.description: Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and Robert Mickey’s “Paths Out of Dixie” help our columnist understand American democracy’s new crisis of authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: The Selma to Montgomery March for Voting Rights, 1965.

item.title: Biden Concedes Defeat on Climate Bill as Manchin and Inflation Upend Agenda
item.description: Rising prices, party infighting and the aftershocks from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine have undercut the president’s plans to speed an energy transition.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.media:description: President Biden has been mindful of the political toll that high gas prices have exacted on his presidency, even as he has tried to push climate action through Congress.

item.title: Brittney Griner Had Prescription for Drug She Brought to Russia, Lawyers Say
item.description: As the W.N.B.A. star’s drugs trial resumed, her defense team contended that she had packed a banned narcotic in her luggage because of “an oversight.”
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner in Khimki, outside of Moscow, ahead of her trial on Friday.

item.title: Russia hammers Mykolaiv again, hitting two universities in the southern city.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: State Emergency Service of Ukraine, via Reuters
item.media:description: A still from a video released by the State Emergency Service of Ukraine on Friday showed a firefighter working at the site of a strike in Mykolaiv.

item.title: Cryptomining Capacity in U.S. Rivals Energy Use of Houston, Findings Show
item.description: The findings, by a congressional investigation, highlight how the surge in activity has caused consumers’ electrical bills to rise and makes it harder to fight global warming.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: A Bitcoin mining facility in Texas. Members of Congress are examining the environmental impact of virtual currencies.

item.title: Saudis Made Trump’s Visit an Extravaganza.
item.description: The Saudis lavished attention on President Donald J. Trump during his first visit in 2017, but President Biden has been more critical of the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia rolled out the red carpet for President Donald J. Trump when he visited in 2017. Portraits of Mr. Trump and King Salman were projected onto the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Riyadh.

item.title: Australia Shifts Its Tone at the Pacific Islands Forum
item.description: Australia, which has been accused of taking a dismissive stance in the past toward island nations, spent the week trying to “show respect” and build its influence.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia, center, with Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama of Fiji, second from left, at the Pacific Islands Forum on Thursday.

item.title: DJ Suonandajie and Other Chinese Players Sets Sights on MLB Draft
item.description: Players from China have signed as international free agents, but a new wave of recruits is trying a different path: attending a U.S. college to become eligible for the draft.
item.dc:creator: Brad Lefton
item.media:credit: Amy Kontras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A speedy outfielder from Qinghai, a Chinese province in the autonomous region of Tibet, DJ will be on scholarship at Rockhurst University in the fall.

item.title: America’s Homelessness Crisis Is Getting Worse
item.description: The homelessness crisis is getting worse.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless encampment in Los Angeles.

item.title: Xi Jinping Visits Xinjiang for the First Time Since Crackdown
item.description: State media have used Xi Jinping’s visits to Hong Kong and, now, Xinjiang to bolster his image as a leader who subdued turbulence on China’s periphery.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Qin
item.media:description: A photo released by Chinese state media showing Xi Jinping visiting Urumqi, the regional capital, on Wednesday. Uyghur activists said the propaganda campaign could not disguise the reality of the mass detentions in the region.

item.title: German Military Officer Known as Franco A. Found Guilty of Plotting Terrorism
item.description: The officer, who had posed as a Syrian refugee, was sentenced to five and a half years in prison for a far-right plot to assassinate prominent public figures.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Boris Roessler/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: A security guard in a Frankfurt courtroom removed handcuffs from Franco A., who was convicted of plotting terrorism, illegal possession of weapons, and fraud for trying to pass himself off as a refugee.

item.title: In a Twist, Old Coal Plants Help Deliver Renewable Power. Here’s How.
item.description: The sites, once a source of greenhouse gases, have a useful feature: They’re wired to the electricity grid. For new ventures like solar farms, that can save a lot of time and money.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Silos of ash and other waste at the retired Brayton Point Power Station in Somerset, Mass. The site will be repurposed to link a wind farm to the Massachusetts power grid.

item.title: How Joe Manchin Doomed the Democrats’ Climate Plan
item.description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia led his party and his president through months of tortured talks, with nothing to show for it as the planet dangerously heats up.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Negotiations collapsed Thursday night, when Democratic leaders said Senator Joe Manchin III rejected all the climate provisions in a proposed spending bill.

item.title: From Mexico to the U.S., an Underground Abortion Pill Network
item.description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
item.dc:creator: Paula Mónaco Felipe, Miguel Tovar, Souleyman Messalti, Caroline Kim and Brent McDonald
item.media:credit: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times
item.media:description:
In July, Verónica Cruz Sánchez, the founder and leader of Las Libres in Guanajuato, Mexico responds to a request for abortion pills from the U.S.
NYTCREDIT: Miguel Tovar for The New York Times

item.title: The many parties involved complicate war crimes investigations.
item.description: Russian attacks on civilians have underscored the need to hold war crimes to account. But the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned against a “stampede” of investigations.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Thursday’s rocket strike on Vinnytsia, Ukraine, was the latest Russian attack that seemed to target a civilian area of a Ukrainian city.

item.title: Philippine Mayors Tell City Workers to Smile or Face Discipline
item.description: “Frowning is not allowed in the municipality!” said the mayor of Mulanay in the Philippines. Many residents applauded his new policy.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russian strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Firefighters, police officers and rescue workers at the site of a missile strike in Vinnytsia, Ukraine, on Thursday that led to at least 23 deaths and dozens of hospitalizations.

item.title: Gaps in Arms Supplies to Ukraine Point to Countries’ Divergent Strategies
item.description: Beyond logistical issues, the uneven flow of arms to Ukraine hints at differences among allies about whether Russia should be punished or eventually accommodated.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops fired a a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer at Russian positions last month in the Donetsk region.

item.title: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
item.description: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A textile factory in Nantong, China. China’s economy in the second quarter expanded 0.4 percent from a year earlier.

item.title: Macron warns of ‘likely risk’ France will be cut off from Russian natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Thomas Padilla/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France said that as the war in Ukraine continued, its economic impact on his country would become more acute.

item.title: Sharp Drop in Childhood Vaccinations Threatens Millions of Lives
item.description: Pandemic lockdowns, misinformation campaigns, conflicts, climate crises and other problems diverted resources and contributed to the largest backslide in routine immunization in 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Polio vaccinations at a bus station in Jammu, India, in February. India, Nigeria, Indonesia, Ethiopia and the Philippines recorded the highest numbers of children who had missed out on vaccines.

item.title: Biden and Israel Remain Divided on Handling Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: Amid declarations of the strong friendship between Israel and the United States, the differing approaches to the best way to stop Iran’s nuclear program were evident on Mr. Biden’s trip to Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Yair Lapid of Israel at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Jerusalem on Thursday.
